name: Maha Shivaratri
title: The Great Night of Lord Shiva
description: Maha Shivaratri is one of the most significant festivals dedicated to Lord Shiva. Observed on the 14th night of the new moon in the month of Phalguna, it represents the cosmic dance of creation, preservation, and destruction.
significance: Commemorates the marriage of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati, and celebrates the cosmic dance of Shiva that maintains the balance of the universe.

seo.description: Complete guide to Maha Shivaratri festival with rituals, stories, bhajans, aartis, fasting, and celebrations. Learn the significance of the Great Night of Lord Shiva.

sections.title: Welcome to Maha Shivaratri
sections.content: Maha Shivaratri, the 'Great Night of Shiva', is one of the most sacred Hindu festivals dedicated to Lord Shiva. Devotees observe fasts and perform night-long vigils to honor the supreme deity.

sections.title: Historical Significance
sections.content: Maha Shivaratri has ancient origins and is mentioned in various Hindu scriptures. The festival holds great spiritual significance and is believed to be the night when Lord Shiva performed the cosmic dance of Tandava.

sections.title: Famous Stories
sections.content: Maha Shivaratri is associated with several important stories from Hindu mythology.

subsections.title: Shiva-Parvati Marriage
subsections.content: One of the most significant stories is the marriage of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati. Parvati undertook intense penance to win Shiva's heart, who was in deep meditation. Her unwavering devotion led Shiva to accept her as his consort.

subsections.title: The Churning of the Ocean
subsections.content: During the cosmic churning of the ocean (Samudra Manthan), a deadly poison called Halahala emerged that threatened to destroy the universe. Lord Shiva drank the poison and held it in his throat, which turned blue, earning him the name Nilakantha.

sections.title: How Maha Shivaratri is Celebrated
sections.content: Maha Shivaratri is celebrated with fasting, night-long vigils, and elaborate pooja ceremonies.

subsections.title: Night-long Vigil
subsections.content: Devotees stay awake throughout the night, performing pooja at four different intervals (prahars). They chant 'Om Namah Shivaya' and listen to Shiva stories.

subsections.title: Temple Visits
subsections.content: People visit Shiva temples throughout the day and night. Major Shiva temples like Kashi Vishwanath, Somnath, and Amarnath see huge gatherings of devotees.

sections.title: Rituals and Pooja
sections.content: Maha Shivaratri rituals include elaborate ceremonies and offerings to Lord Shiva.

subsections.title: Shivaling Abhishekam
subsections.content: The Shivaling is bathed with water, milk, honey, curd, and ghee while chanting Vedic mantras. This ritual is believed to please Lord Shiva immensely.

subsections.title: Bilva Leaves Offering
subsections.content: Offering Bilva (bel) leaves to the Shivaling is considered highly auspicious. It is believed that Goddess Lakshmi resides in these leaves.

sections.title: Shivaratri Special Foods
sections.content: Simple sattvic foods are consumed during Shivaratri fasting.

subsections.title: Fasting Foods
subsections.content: Popular fasting foods include fruits, milk, curd, nuts, and dishes made from buckwheat and singhara flour. These foods are pure and sattvic in nature.

subsections.title: Prasad Offerings
subsections.content: Traditional prasad includes Panchamrit (mixture of milk, curd, honey, ghee, and sugar), fruits, and dry fruits.

sections.title: Shivaratri Bhajans
sections.content: Devotional songs sung during Shivaratri to honor Lord Shiva.

subsections.title: Shiv Tandav Stotram
subsections.english:
With his neck consecrated by the flow of water that flows from his hair,
And on his neck a snake, which is hung like a garland
subsections.meaning: This powerful stotram describes Lord Shiva's cosmic dance and divine attributes.

sections.title: Shivaratri Aartis
sections.content: Traditional aartis performed during Shivaratri celebrations.

subsections.title: Om Jai Shiv Omkara
subsections.english:
Om Jai Shiv Omkara, Lord Om Jai Shiv Omkara
Brahma Vishnu Sadashiv, with Ardhangini (half-body as Parvati)
subsections.meaning: This aarti praises Lord Shiva in his various forms and acknowledges his divine consort Parvati.
